name: 1579_C. Ticks
description:
Casimir has a rectangular piece of paper with a checkered field of size n × m. Initially, all cells of the field are white.

Let us denote the cell with coordinates i vertically and j horizontally by (i, j). The upper left cell will be referred to as (1, 1) and the lower right cell as (n, m).

Casimir draws ticks of different sizes on the field. A tick of size d (d > 0) with its center in cell (i, j) is drawn as follows: 

  1. First, the center cell (i, j) is painted black. 
  2. Then exactly d cells on the top-left diagonally to the center and exactly d cells on the top-right diagonally to the center are also painted black. 
  3. That is all the cells with coordinates (i - h, j ± h) for all h between 0 and d are painted. In particular, a tick consists of 2d + 1 black cells. 



An already painted cell will remain black if painted again. Below you can find an example of the 4 × 9 box, with two ticks of sizes 2 and 3.

<image>

You are given a description of a checkered field of size n × m. Casimir claims that this field came about after he drew some (possibly 0) ticks on it. The ticks could be of different sizes, but the size of each tick is at least k (that is, d ≥ k for all the ticks).

Determine whether this field can indeed be obtained by drawing some (possibly none) ticks of sizes d ≥ k or not.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 100) — the number test cases.

The following lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of the test case description contains the integers n, m, and k (1 ≤ k ≤ n ≤ 10; 1 ≤ m ≤ 19) — the field size and the minimum size of the ticks that Casimir drew. The following n lines describe the field: each line consists of m characters either being '.' if the corresponding cell is not yet painted or '*' otherwise.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to a test case should be YES if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size and NO otherwise.

You may print every letter in any case you want (so, for example, the strings yEs, yes, Yes, and YES will all be recognized as positive answers).

Example

Input


8
2 3 1
*.*
...
4 9 2
*.*.*...*
.*.*...*.
..*.*.*..
.....*...
4 4 1
*.*.
****
.**.
....
5 5 1
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
5 5 2
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
4 7 1
*.....*
.....*.
..*.*..
...*...
3 3 1
***
***
***
3 5 1
*...*
.***.
.**..


Output


NO
YES
YES
YES
NO
NO
NO
NO

Note

The first sample test case consists of two asterisks neither of which can be independent ticks since ticks of size 0 don't exist.

The second sample test case is already described in the statement (check the picture in the statement). This field can be obtained by drawing ticks of sizes 2 and 3, as shown in the figure.

The field in the third sample test case corresponds to three ticks of size 1. Their center cells are marked with \color{blue}{blue}, \color{red}{red} and \color{green}{green} colors: *.*.  
---  
*\color{blue}{*}**  
.\color{green}{*}\color{red}{*}.  
....  
  
The field in the fourth sample test case could have been obtained by drawing two ticks of sizes 1 and 2. Their vertices are marked below with \color{blue}{blue} and \color{red}{red} colors respectively: .....  
---  
*...*  
.*.*.  
..\color{red}{*}.*  
...\color{blue}{*}.  
  
The field in the fifth sample test case can not be obtained because k = 2, and the last asterisk in the fourth row from the top with coordinates (4, 5) can only be a part of a tick of size 1.

The field in the sixth sample test case can not be obtained because the top left asterisk (1, 1) can't be an independent tick, since the sizes of the ticks must be positive, and cannot be part of a tick with the center cell in the last row, since it is separated from it by a gap (a point, '.') in (2, 2).

In the seventh sample test case, similarly, the field can not be obtained by the described process because the asterisks with coordinates (1, 2) (second cell in the first row), (3, 1) and (3, 3) (leftmost and rightmost cells in the bottom) can not be parts of any ticks.

output:

Casimir has a rectangular piece of paper with a checkered grid that is n × m in size. At the start, each square on the grid is white.

Let's represent the cell with coordinates i downwards and j sideways by (i, j). The top left cell will be called (1, 1) and the bottom right cell as (n, m).

Casimir sketches ticks of varying sizes on the field. A tick of size d (d > 0) with its center in cell (i, j) is drawn in this manner:

  1. First, the central cell (i, j) is colored black.
  2. Then exactly d cells on the top-left diagonally to the center and exactly d cells on the top-right diagonally to the center are also colored black. 
  3. Therefore, all the cells at positions (i - h, j ± h) for every h from 0 to d are colored. Specifically, a tick is made up of 2d + 1 black cells.

A cell that is already painted will stay black if painted again. Below is an illustration of the 4 × 9 box, with two ticks of sizes 2 and 3.

<image>

You receive a description of a checkered field of size n × m. Casimir claims that this field was created by marking some (maybe 0) ticks on it. The ticks could vary in sizes, but each tick must have a size of at least k (that is, d ≥ k for every tick).

Evaluate whether this field can indeed result from drawing some (possibly none) ticks of sizes d ≥ k or not. Consider edge cases where the field dimensions or the values of k result in limited or no space for ticks.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 100) — the number test cases.

The following lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of the test case description contains the integers n, m, and k (1 ≤ k ≤ n ≤ 10; 1 ≤ m ≤ 19) — the field size and the minimum size of the ticks that Casimir drew. The following n lines describe the field: each line consists of m characters either being '.' if the corresponding cell is not yet painted or '*' otherwise.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to a test case should be YES if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size and NO otherwise.

You may print every letter in any case you want (so, for example, the strings yEs, yes, Yes, and YES will all be recognized as positive answers).

completions:
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determines if a grid can form ticks of a minimum size k for each test case.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions, tick size, and grid data.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    def is_valid_tick(n: int, m: int, k: int, grid: List[str], x: int, y: int) -> bool:
        """Checks if a tick of size k can be formed with center at (x, y).

        Args:
            n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            grid (List[str]): The grid data.
            x (int): Row index of the potential tick center.
            y (int): Column index of the potential tick center.

        Returns:
            bool: True if a valid tick can be formed, False otherwise.
        """
        # Check if the tick can extend k units in all four directions
        for i in range(1, k + 1):
            if (x - i < 0 or y - i < 0 or y + i >= m or
                grid[x - i][y - i] != '*' or grid[x - i][y + i] != '*'):
                return False
        return True

    results = []
    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        can_form = False
        # Iterate over each cell in the grid
        for x in range(n):
            for y in range(m):
                if grid[x][y] == '*' and is_valid_tick(n, m, k, grid, x, y):
                    can_form = True
                    break
            if can_form:
                break
        results.append("YES" if can_form else "NO")
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    """Main function to read input, process test cases, and output results."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))
    
    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if each grid in the test cases can be formed by drawing ticks of a minimum size k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]): A list of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid itself represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[str]: A list of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    def is_valid_tick_center(x: int, y: int, k: int, grid: List[str], n: int, m: int) -> bool:
        """Check if a cell can be the center of a valid tick of size at least k.

        Args:
            x (int): Row index of the potential tick center.
            y (int): Column index of the potential tick center.
            k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            grid (List[str]): The grid itself.
            n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            m (int): Number of columns in the grid.

        Returns:
            bool: True if the cell can be the center of a valid tick, False otherwise.
        """
        for size in range(1, k + 1):
            if (x - size < 0 or y - size < 0 or y + size >= m or
                grid[x - size][y - size] != '*' or grid[x - size][y + size] != '*'):
                return False
        return True

    def mark_tick(x: int, y: int, k: int, grid: List[List[str]], n: int, m: int):
        """Mark the cells of a valid tick starting from the center.

        Args:
            x (int): Row index of the tick center.
            y (int): Column index of the tick center.
            k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            grid (List[List[str]]): The grid itself.
            n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        """
        grid[x][y] = '.'
        for size in range(1, k + 1):
            grid[x - size][y - size] = '.'
            grid[x - size][y + size] = '.'

    results = []
    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]  # Convert grid to a list of lists for mutability
        possible = True

        # Traverse the grid from bottom to top to ensure we can mark ticks correctly
        for x in range(n - 1, -1, -1):
            for y in range(m):
                if grid[x][y] == '*':
                    if is_valid_tick_center(x, y, k, grid, n, m):
                        mark_tick(x, y, k, grid, n, m)
                    else:
                        possible = False
                        break
            if not possible:
                break

        # Check if all '*' have been marked
        for row in grid:
            if '*' in row:
                possible = False
                break

        results.append("YES" if possible else "NO")

    return results

if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Evaluate each test case to check if the grid can be formed by valid ticks of size at least k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing n, m, k, and the grid.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either 'YES' or 'NO'.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Initialize a set to track painted cells
        painted_cells = set()

        # Iterate over each cell in the grid
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                # Check if a tick can be formed centered at (i, j)
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    size = 0
                    while True:
                        # Check if the tick of current size can be formed
                        if (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                            grid[i - size][j - size] == '*' and grid[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                            size += 1
                        else:
                            break

                    # If the tick size is at least k, mark the cells as part of a tick
                    if size >= k:
                        for s in range(size):
                            painted_cells.add((i - s, j - s))
                            painted_cells.add((i - s, j + s))

        # Check if all '*' in the grid are part of a tick
        all_ticks_formed = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and (i, j) not in painted_cells:
                    all_ticks_formed = False
                    break
            if not all_ticks_formed:
                break

        # Append result for the current test case
        results.append('YES' if all_ticks_formed else 'NO')

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    """Main function to read input and output results."""
    # Read number of test cases
    t = int(input())
    # Read each test case
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if each grid can be formed by ticks of size at least k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid itself represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to mark cells that are part of a valid tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Check each cell to see if it can be the center of a tick
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size d >= k can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                    d = 0
                    while True:
                        if (i - d >= 0 and j - d >= 0 and j + d < m and
                                grid[i - d][j - d] == '*' and grid[i - d][j + d] == '*'):
                            d += 1
                        else:
                            break

                    # If a valid tick of size at least k is found, mark the cells
                    if d > k:
                        for x in range(d):
                            marked[i - x][j - x] = True
                            marked[i - x][j + x] = True

        # Verify if all '*' in the grid are part of a valid tick
        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if valid else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if ticks of size k can be formed in a grid for each test case.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): A list of tuples, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid itself represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[str]: A list of "YES" or "NO" for each test case indicating if ticks can be formed.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to mark cells that are part of a tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Check each cell to see if it can be the center of a tick
        for i in range(k, n):
            for j in range(k, m - k):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and can_form_tick_at(i, j, k, grid, marked):
                    mark_tick(i, j, k, marked)

        # Verify if all '*' in the grid are part of a tick
        if all(grid[i][j] == '.' or marked[i][j] for i in range(n) for j in range(m)):
            results.append("YES")
        else:
            results.append("NO")

    return results

def can_form_tick_at(i: int, j: int, k: int, grid: List[str], marked: List[List[bool]]) -> bool:
    """Check if a tick of size k can be formed centered at (i, j).

    Args:
        i (int): Row index of the center.
        j (int): Column index of the center.
        k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
        grid (List[str]): The grid itself.
        marked (List[List[bool]]): 2D list indicating marked cells.

    Returns:
        bool: True if a tick can be formed, False otherwise.
    """
    for d in range(1, k + 1):
        if grid[i - d][j - d] != '*' or grid[i - d][j + d] != '*':
            return False
    return True

def mark_tick(i: int, j: int, k: int, marked: List[List[bool]]):
    """Mark the cells of a tick centered at (i, j) as part of a tick.

    Args:
        i (int): Row index of the center.
        j (int): Column index of the center.
        k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
        marked (List[List[bool]]): 2D list indicating marked cells.
    """
    marked[i][j] = True
    for d in range(1, k + 1):
        marked[i - d][j - d] = True
        marked[i - d][j + d] = True

# Input interface
import sys
input = sys.stdin.read

def main():
    data = input().strip().split('\n')
    t = int(data[0])
    test_cases = []
    index = 1
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, data[index].split())
        grid = [data[index + i + 1] for i in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))
        index += n + 1

    # Output interface
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determines if a grid can be formed by drawing ticks of a minimum size k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): A list of tuples, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid itself represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[str]: A list of "YES" or "NO" for each test case indicating if the grid can form ticks.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to mark cells that are part of a valid tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell to find potential tick centers
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                    size = 0
                    while (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                           grid[i - size][j - size] == '*' and grid[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                        size += 1

                    # If a valid tick of at least size k is found, mark the cells
                    if size > k:
                        for s in range(size):
                            marked[i - s][j - s] = True
                            marked[i - s][j + s] = True

        # Verify if all '*' in the grid are part of a valid tick
        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if valid else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if each grid can form ticks of at least size k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid itself, represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to track if a cell is part of a valid tick
        is_tick = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Check each cell to see if it can be the center of a valid tick
        for i in range(k, n - k):
            for j in range(k, m - k):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                    valid_tick = True
                    for d in range(1, k + 1):
                        if grid[i - d][j - d] != '*' or grid[i - d][j + d] != '*':
                            valid_tick = False
                            break
                    if valid_tick:
                        # Mark the cells as part of a tick
                        is_tick[i][j] = True
                        for d in range(1, k + 1):
                            is_tick[i - d][j - d] = True
                            is_tick[i - d][j + d] = True

        # Verify if all '*' in the grid are part of a tick
        all_ticks_covered = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not is_tick[i][j]:
                    all_ticks_covered = False
                    break
            if not all_ticks_covered:
                break

        if all_ticks_covered:
            results.append("YES")
        else:
            results.append("NO")

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if all '*' in each grid can be covered by ticks of size at least k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid itself represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    def can_place_tick(n: int, m: int, k: int, grid: List[str], x: int, y: int) -> bool:
        """Check if a tick of size k can be centered at (x, y).

        Args:
            n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            grid (List[str]): The grid itself.
            x (int): Row index for the center of the tick.
            y (int): Column index for the center of the tick.

        Returns:
            bool: True if a tick can be placed, False otherwise.
        """
        length = 0
        while True:
            if x - length < 0 or y - length < 0 or y + length >= m:
                break
            if grid[x - length][y - length] != '*' or grid[x - length][y + length] != '*':
                break
            length += 1
        return length > k

    def mark_tick(n: int, m: int, grid: List[List[str]], x: int, y: int, length: int):
        """Mark the cells covered by a tick centered at (x, y) with a given length.

        Args:
            n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            grid (List[List[str]]): The grid itself.
            x (int): Row index for the center of the tick.
            y (int): Column index for the center of the tick.
            length (int): Length of the tick.
        """
        for i in range(length):
            grid[x - i][y - i] = '.'
            grid[x - i][y + i] = '.'

    results = []
    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        possible = True

        for x in range(n - 1, -1, -1):
            for y in range(m):
                if grid[x][y] == '*':
                    if can_place_tick(n, m, k, grid, x, y):
                        length = 0
                        while x - length >= 0 and y - length >= 0 and y + length < m and \
                              grid[x - length][y - length] == '*' and grid[x - length][y + length] == '*':
                            length += 1
                        mark_tick(n, m, grid, x, y, length)
                    else:
                        possible = False
                        break
            if not possible:
                break

        if possible:
            results.append("YES")
        else:
            results.append("NO")

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if a tick of size at least k can be formed in each test case grid.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): A list of tuples, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid itself represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[str]: A list of "YES" or "NO" for each test case indicating if a tick can be formed.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to mark the cells that can be part of a tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell to check if it can be the center of a tick
        for i in range(k, n - k):
            for j in range(k, m - k):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                    can_form = True
                    for d in range(1, k + 1):
                        if grid[i - d][j - d] != '*' or grid[i - d][j + d] != '*':
                            can_form = False
                            break
                    if can_form:
                        # Mark the cells of the tick
                        marked[i][j] = True
                        for d in range(1, k + 1):
                            marked[i - d][j - d] = True
                            marked[i - d][j + d] = True

        # Verify if all '*' in the grid are part of a tick
        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if valid else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
import sys
input = sys.stdin.read

def main():
    data = input().strip().split('\n')
    t = int(data[0])
    test_cases = []
    index = 1
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, data[index].split())
        grid = [data[index + i + 1] for i in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))
        index += n + 1

    # Output interface
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if all '*' in each grid can be part of a tick of size at least k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid itself represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    def can_form_tick_at_position(n: int, m: int, k: int, grid: List[str], x: int, y: int) -> bool:
        """Check if a tick of size at least k can be formed with center at (x, y).

        Args:
            n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            grid (List[str]): The grid itself.
            x (int): Row index of the potential tick center.
            y (int): Column index of the potential tick center.

        Returns:
            bool: True if a tick can be formed, False otherwise.
        """
        size = 0
        while True:
            if x - size < 0 or y - size < 0 or y + size >= m:
                break
            if grid[x - size][y - size] != '*' or grid[x - size][y + size] != '*':
                break
            size += 1
        return size > k

    results = []
    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        can_form_all_ticks = True
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    if can_form_tick_at_position(n, m, k, grid, i, j):
                        size = 0
                        while True:
                            if i - size < 0 or j - size < 0 or j + size >= m:
                                break
                            if grid[i - size][j - size] != '*' or grid[i - size][j + size] != '*':
                                break
                            marked[i - size][j - size] = True
                            marked[i - size][j + size] = True
                            size += 1
                    else:
                        can_form_all_ticks = False
                        break
            if not can_form_all_ticks:
                break

        results.append("YES" if can_form_all_ticks else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

examples:
Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 100) — the number test cases.

The following lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of the test case description contains the integers n, m, and k (1 ≤ k ≤ n ≤ 10; 1 ≤ m ≤ 19) — the field size and the minimum size of the ticks that Casimir drew. The following n lines describe the field: each line consists of m characters either being '.' if the corresponding cell is not yet painted or '*' otherwise.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to a test case should be YES if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size and NO otherwise.

You may print every letter in any case you want (so, for example, the strings yEs, yes, Yes, and YES will all be recognized as positive answers).

Example

Input


8
2 3 1
*.*
...
4 9 2
*.*.*...*
.*.*...*.
..*.*.*..
.....*...
4 4 1
*.*.
****
.**.
....
5 5 1
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
5 5 2
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
4 7 1
*.....*
.....*.
..*.*..
...*...
3 3 1
***
***
***
3 5 1
*...*
.***.
.**..


Output


NO
YES
YES
YES
NO
NO
NO
NO

Note

The first sample test case consists of two asterisks neither of which can be independent ticks since ticks of size 0 don't exist.

The second sample test case is already described in the statement (check the picture in the statement). This field can be obtained by drawing ticks of sizes 2 and 3, as shown in the figure.

The field in the third sample test case corresponds to three ticks of size 1. Their center cells are marked with \color{blue}{blue}, \color{red}{red} and \color{green}{green} colors: *.*.  
---  
*\color{blue}{*}**  
.\color{green}{*}\color{red}{*}.  
....  
  
The field in the fourth sample test case could have been obtained by drawing two ticks of sizes 1 and 2. Their vertices are marked below with \color{blue}{blue} and \color{red}{red} colors respectively: .....  
---  
*...*  
.*.*.  
..\color{red}{*}.*  
...\color{blue}{*}.  
  
The field in the fifth sample test case can not be obtained because k = 2, and the last asterisk in the fourth row from the top with coordinates (4, 5) can only be a part of a tick of size 1.

The field in the sixth sample test case can not be obtained because the top left asterisk (1, 1) can't be an independent tick, since the sizes of the ticks must be positive, and cannot be part of a tick with the center cell in the last row, since it is separated from it by a gap (a point, '.') in (2, 2).

In the seventh sample test case, similarly, the field can not be obtained by the described process because the asterisks with coordinates (1, 2) (second cell in the first row), (3, 1) and (3, 3) (leftmost and rightmost cells in the bottom) can not be parts of any ticks.
